Metric: Level of availability of harm reduction services and harm reduction scale up

Metric: Prevalence of alcohol and drugs in accidents, and interventions to increase road safety
Indicators: In 2010, the number of serious drug-related injuries will be 545 at most {Une politique globale et intégrée en matière de drogues pour la Belgique, 2010, p.33} ~ For 2008 at the latest, the amount of driving under the influence of drugs shall not exceed 1% and the extent of driving under the influence of alcohol combined with the taking of illicit drugs shall not exceed 0,5% {Une politique globale et intégrée en matière de drogues pour la Belgique, 2010, p.33} ~ 1 in 10 drivers must be checked annually for illegal drugs in the traffic. This corresponds to 625,000 checks per year {Une politique globale et intégrée en matière de drogues pour la Belgique, 2010, p.33} ~ The subjective risk of being caught must be such that at least 90% of the Belgian population in possession of a driving license believe that the risk of being taken under the influence of the driver Alcohol and / or illicit drugs is very high {Une politique globale et intégrée en matière de drogues pour la Belgique, 2010, p.33} ~ The aim is to increase the current number of drug checks and to ensure that controls are better targeted at the locations and times, as well as the themes and target groups whose drug use - according to analyses of road accidents - show that they contribute substantially to road fatalities (reduce road fatalities) {Une politique globale et intégrée en matière de drogues pour la Belgique, 2010, p.34} ~

Opioids; Methadone; Buprenorphine; Burprenorphine/Naloxone; PIEDs; More than one; Other; Not reported) and survey year {Australian Needle and Syringe Program Survey: National Data Report, 2018, p.13} ~ Number (percentage) of respondents who have ever injected opioids (Yes; No; Not reported) and survey year {Australian Needle and Syringe Program Survey: National Data Report, 2018, p.13} ~ Number (percentage) of respondents by frequency of injection last month (Not last month; Less than weekly; Weekly not daily; Daily or more; Not reported) and survey year {Australian Needle and Syringe Program Survey: National Data Report, 2018, p.13} ~ National lifetime and recent (past 12 months) injection of illicit drugs (%) among people aged 14 years or older, 2001-2016 {Needle Syringe Program National Minimum Data Collection, 2018, p.31} ~ Trends in the estimated number of ‘regular’ PWID in Australia 2000/01-2017/18 {Needle Syringe Program National Minimum Data Collection, 2018, p.33} ~

Metric: Coverage of treatment, without mention of medication-assisted treatment (MAT)
Indicators: Level of capability among generalist health, community, welfare and support services workers to prevent and reduce AOD harm. {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.28} ~ number of specialist drug treatments provided for meth/amphetamines {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.8} ~ Drug treatment episodes {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p. 42} ~ Number of formally accredited AOD services. {National Aboriginal Torres Strait Islander Peoples Drug Strategy, 2014-2019, p.33 & p.35} ~ Alcohol and other drug attributable hospital admissions and ambulance attendances {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.42} ~ Number (percentage) of respondents who participated ever in any treatment/therapy for drug use (No; Yes; Not reported) and survey year {Australian Needle and Syringe Program Survey: National Data Report, 2018, p.15} ~ Number of principal opioid-related hospital admissions/separations per million persons aged 15-54 years, 2005/06-2014/15 {Needle Syringe Program National Minimum Data Collection, 2018, p.32} ~

Metric: Coverage of treatment, without mention of medication-assisted treatment (MAT) by age
Level of access to opioid substitution treatment and medication assisted treatment (OST/MAT)
Indicators: Opioid pharmacotherapy clients {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.42} ~ Number (percentage) of respondents who have a history of methadone maintenance treatment/buprenorphine (Subutex) treatment/burprenorphine-naloxone treatment (Suboxone) and survey year {Australian Needle and Syringe Program Survey: National Data Report, 2018, p.15} ~

Metric: Level of coverage of inpatient treatment
Indicators: The number of hospitalisations related to methamphetamine between 2009–10 and 2013–14 {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.8} ~

Metric: Proportion of people who use drugs enrolled in voluntary treatment
Proportion of people who use drugs enrolled in coerced treatment
Proportion of people who use drugs enrolled in compulsory treatment
Indicators: number of diversions for cannabis-related offences {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.4} ~

Metric: Presence of prevention programming in law enforcement
Presence of prevention programming in the media
Presence of prevention programming in schools
Indicators: Availability of workforce development resources and programs for the education sector enabling them to enhance their capacity to prevent and reduce AOD harms among students. {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.31} ~ Number of workforce programs to develop effective linkages between the education sector (primary, secondary, VET, tertiary) and specialist AOD sector (service providers, registered training organisations and research agencies) {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.31} ~

Metric: Presence of prevention programming in the workplace
Indicators: Availability of workforce development resources and programs for generalist workers to increase their capacity to prevent and reduce AOD harm. {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.28} ~ Availability of specialist AOD professionals to act as consultants to generalist staff {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.28} ~ Percentage of specialist AOD prevention and treatment staff receiving mentoring and support. {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.16} ~ Career satisfaction enhanced and stress and burnout rates minimised among specialist AOD prevention and treatment staff {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.16} ~

Metric: Presence of prevention programming for youth and the community
Indicators: Prevalence of Australians identified methamphetamine as the illicit drug of most concern to the community {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p. 31} ~ Percentage of AOD roles that have child and family sensitive practice defined as a key workforce capability {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.20} ~ Proportion of AOD agencies which have implemented organisational policies, guidelines, practices and workforce development measures to support child and family sensitive practice. {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.20} ~ Availability of workforce development resources and programs for the AOD sector focused on enhancing child and family sensitive practice. {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.20} ~ Number of AOD agencies that have developed links with child wellbeing/welfare/ family violence services. {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.20} ~

Metric: Presence of other demand reduction metrics
Indicators: Nationally consistent terminology to describe the roles of the specialist AOD prevention and treatment workforce {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.14} ~ Comprehensive knowledge of the extent and nature of the specialist AOD prevention and treatment workforce {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.14} ~ Percentage of agencies providing specialist AOD prevention and treatment services that report they are able to attract and retain requisite staff {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.16} ~ Appropriate turnover rates in specialist AOD prevention and treatment services {National Alcohol and other Drug Workforce Development Strategy, 2015-2018, p.16} ~ Number of methamphetamine related hospital separations {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.9} ~ Australian spending on alcohol and other drug treatment, funder and source 2012–13 {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.13} ~

Metric: Size and value of the illegal drug market
Indicators: Australian injecting drug users reporting that it is easy or very easy to access ice {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.19} ~ the availability and purity of methamphetamine (as indicated by more domestic seizures, border detections and arrests) {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.12} ~ the number of prescriptions for opioid prescriptions subsidised by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.33} ~ The availability of illegal drugs, as perceived by people who use illegal drugs {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.42} ~

Metric: Level of procedures related to crop eradication
Number of arrests, seizures, and offences
Indicators: Kilograms of ice seized at the Australian border {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.9} ~ Arrests for amphetamine-type stimulant drug offences {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.18} ~ Illicit drugs and precursors seized {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.42} ~ Domestically and at the border, the number in tons of drugs seized and its estimated price (2013-2014) {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.18} ~ % of adult detainees interviewed as part of the Drug Use Monitoring in Australia program reported that their alcohol and other drug use contributed to their current detention by police {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p. 28} ~  National number of illicit drug arrests, 2005/06-2016/17 {Needle Syringe Program National Minimum Data Collection, 2018, p.31} ~ National number of illicit drug seizures, 2005/06-2016/17 {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.4; Needle Syringe Program National Minimum Data Collection, 2018, p.31} ~

Metric: Level of law enforcement activity and interdiction in the market
Indicators: Diversion of licit drugs e.g. pharmaceuticals {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.42} ~

Metric: Price, purity and potency of drugs, and related process indicators
Indicators: National annual median street price for one gram of ice {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.19} ~ National annual median purity of domestically seized methamphetamine {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.19} ~ availability and purity of methamphetamine (as indicated by more domestic seizures, border detections and arrests) {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.12} ~ The purity of illegal drugs {National Drug Strategy, 2017-2026, p.42} ~ Domestically and at the border, the number in tons of drugs seized and its estimated price (2013-2014) {National Ice Action Strategy, 2015, p.18} ~

Bilan statistique des onze premiers mois, 2016, p.3} ~ The number of different psychotropic substances in the form of tablets that have been seized, the number of vials containing psychotropic substances that have been seized, and the number of capsules that have been seized {Activités de lutte contre la drogue et la toxicomanie - Bilan statistique des onze premiers mois, 2016, p.3}~ Quantities seized during the first 11 months of 2015: Cannabis and Resins (Cannabis resin, cannabis herb, cannabis seeds, cannabis plants), Cocaine, Crack, Heroin, Opium (Opium poppy, opium seeds, opium plants), other psychotropic substances (tablets and vials) {Activités de lutte contre la drogue et la toxicomanie - quantity seized in the first 11 months of 2015, quantity seized in the first 11 months of 2016, variation between 2015 and 2016, and % of variation between 2015 and 2016; Detention and use - quantity seized in the first 11 months of 2015, quantity seized in the first 11 months of 2016, variation between 2015 and 2016, and % of variation between 2015 and 2016; Total quantity seized in the first 11 months of 2015, quantity seized in the first 11 months of 2016, variation between 2015 and 2016, and % of variation between 2015 and 2016 {Activités de lutte contre la drogue et la toxicomanie - Indicators: Number of specific structures (i. Reception, referral, and prevention, ii. Risk Reduction/Low Threshold units/Mobile units, iii. Care systems, iv. Rehabilitation) {Programme national de lutte contre la toxicomania, 2009, p.2} ~ Number of IDUs who benefited from the risk reduction program 2009. The target for 2016 is 8,000 for risk reduction program {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.85, p.92} ~ Targets for combined prevention coverage of injecting drug users and current “active” injectors: 1) Number of IDUs (heroin and/or cocaine/crack), all routes of administration combined, benefiting under the DDR programme. (Base value in 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016) 2) Number of active injectors benefiting under the DDR programme (Base value in 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016) {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction 2014, p.35}~

Metric: Presence of needle and syringe programs
Indicators: Number of syringes distributed to IDUs at intervention sites of risk reduction programs {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.92}~

Metric: Prevalence of substance use disorders
Indicators: Prevalence of major problems in adults aged 15 years and over. (National General Population Prevalence Survey, 2003-2006): Alcohol Abuse, Alcohol Dependence, Substance Abuse, Substance Dependence {Programme national de lutte contre la toxicomania, 2009, p.1}~  % of people with substance dependence, and the prevalence in the general population {Stratégie Sectorielle de Santé, 2012-2016, p.71}~ the prevalence of substance dependence of those over 15 in 2006 {Drug Situation and Policy, 2014, p.10}~  The prevalence of substance abuse in 2003, and substance dependence in 2003 (for all substances and routes of administration combined) {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction 2014, p.42}~ % of those who reported abusing or dependence on these substances in 2003 {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction 2014, p.55}~ prevalence of drug abuse amongst 15 year olds in 2006 {Drug Situation and Policy, 2014, p.10}~

Metric: Prevalence of psychiatric comorbidities
Drug-related mortality
Indicators: Number of people living with HIV/AIDS in 2009, and the number who died from AIDS {Drug Situation and Policy, 2014, p.24}~

Metric: Prevalence of drug-related infectious disease
Indicators: prevalence of new HIV infections among injecting drug users {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction 2014, p.34}~ % of new cases of HIV infections due to IDU {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.17} ~ Prevalence (%) HIV among IDUs in 2010, and the target for 2016 <5% {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.84} ~  HIV prevalence among key populations at higher risk of HIV infection (PS, MSM, IDU) {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.92}~ Number of people living with HIV/AIDS in 2009, and the number who died from AIDS {Drug Situation and Policy, 2014, p.24}~ Prevalence of HIV amongst IDUs and that of Hepatitis C {Drug Situation and Policy, 2014, p.25} ~  HIV seropositivity rate (%) among the drug users tested in Nador - 2005 {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction, 2014, p.57}~ HCV seropositivity rates (%) among the drug users tested in Nador and Al Hoceima {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction, 2014, p.57}~  Prevalence (%) of HIV among injecting drug users in 2014 {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction, 2014, p.73}~ % of new HIV infections attributable to injection drug users and their partners in 2014 {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction, 2014, p.73} ~ HIV prevalence in Al Hoceima, Tangier, Nador {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction, 2014, p.73}~

Metric: Proportion of people who use drugs who engage in risky consumption
Indicators: Percentage of IDUs who have shared syringes in the past month - 2005 {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.19}~ Sharing rate of needles in the previous month (%), sharing rate for water used for preparation (%), sharing rate of spoons (%), and the sharing rate of cotton filters (%), in Tangier and Nador in 2010-2011 {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction, 2014, p.75}~ % of people who have reused their needle in the past month, % of people who had used already used needles the last time they injected drugs in Tangier and Nador, 2010-2011 {Annual Report of the National Observatory of Drugs and Addiction, 2014, p.75}~

Metric: Proportion of people who use drugs who engage in safe consumption practices
Indicators: % of IDUs reported using sterile injection equipment (Core values - year 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016) {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.42} ~  Percentage of IDU reporting using sterile injection equipment at last injection {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p. 84, p.92}~

Metric: Coverage of services for the prevention, testing, and treatment of bloodborne diseases
Indicators: Targets for combined prevention coverage of key populations at higher risk of infection: IDU (Core Values in 2010, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, Coverage Estimated in 2016%) IDU- Methadone (Core values in 2010, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, coverage estimated in 2016%) {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.42}~ Percentage of key individuals at risk of HIV infection (PS, MSM, IDU) who have had an HIV test in the last 12 months and who are aware of the outcome {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.93}~ Percentage of IDUs who were screened for HIV {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.19}~  % of IDUs who get screened for HIV and follow up with their test results – 2012 {Drug Situation and Policy, 2014, p.26}~ % of Moroccans who had access to antiretroviral therapy in 2010 {Drug Situation and Policy, 2014, p.26}~ Coverage of prevention, care and support activities (number of persons): IDU (2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016) {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.71}~ Number of people (new and old) among key populations at higher risk of infection or vulnerable (PS, MSM, IDU, working people, detainees, migrants, road workers, etc.) who benefited from prevention programs in 2010 Level of priority regions {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.22}~ Percentage of key people at higher risk of HIV infection (PS, MSM, IDU) affected by HIV prevention programs {Plan Stratégique Nationale de Lutte Contre le Sida, 2012-2016, p.92} ~

Metric: Drug-related mortality

Amphetamine Use 2015/16: New Zealand Health Survey, 2016, p.2, p.3; Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.20, p.22, p.43, p.44, p.46, p.47, p.49, p.69, p.71, p.77, p.84, p.86, p.87, p.98, p.99, p.111, p.113, p.118, p.120, p.125, p.142, p.144, p.155, p.163, p.189, p.191} ~ Number of different drugs used in the last 12 months, among past-year drug users and total population aged 16–64 years (unadjusted prevalence and estimated number of adults) {Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.22} ~ Location of using drugs by type (amphetamines, BZP party pills) in the last 12 months, among past-year drug users aged 16–64 years (unadjusted prevalence) {Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.23, p.46, p.89, p.191} ~ Prevalence of people who have reported using drugs at some point in their lifetime by type of drug (any drug, cannabis, ecstasy, cocaine), by age and by sex {Cannabis Use 2012/13: New Zealand Health Survey, 2015, p.2; Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.16, p.39, p.41, p.65, p.66, p.94} ~ Prevalence of people who have reported ever using drugs, by age and sex, and by type of drug (cannabis, amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine, hallucinogenic drugs, LSD or synthetic hallucinogens, naturally occurring hallucinogens, ketamine, kava, GHB, solvents, BZP party pills) {Cannabis Use 2012/13: New Zealand Health Survey, 2015, p.17; Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.39, p.41, p.66, p.68, p.81, p.83, p.94, p.95, p.96, p.97, p.108, p.110, p.115, p.117, p.122, p.124, p.128, p.138, p.152, p.154, p.174, p.176, p.185, p.187} ~ Estimated ratio of people who have used drugs by type of drug (cannabis, ecstasy, amphetamines), and by age {National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.1, p.8} ~ Average age of first use of drugs by type (cannabis, ecstasy, amphetamines, cocaine, prescription stimulants, hallucinogenic drugs, naturally occurring hallucinogens, kava, GHB) {National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.9; Metric: Number of people who use drugs
Indicators: Over a lifetime, percentage of New Zealanders who will have tried an illegal drug {National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.1} ~

Metric: Prevalence of drug use by mode of administration (oral, mucosa, inhalation, and injection)
Indicators: Prevalence of people who have ever injected drugs for recreational purposes in lifetime, past 12 months, by age group and sex {Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.180} ~ Age of first injecting for recreational purposes by age group and sex {Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.181, p.182} ~ percentage of people with hepatitis C virus infection that report a history of intravenous drug use {National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.10} ~

Metric: Coverage of treatment, without mention of medication-assisted treatment (MAT)
Coverage of treatment, without mention of medication-assisted treatment (MAT) by age
Indicators: Prevalence of people who have ever used drugs by type (cannabis, amphetamines, BZP party pills) that have received help to reduce their level of drug use at some point in their lifetime, in the past 12 months, by age group, by sex {Cannabis Use 2012/13: New Zealand Health Survey, 2015, p.13, p.28; Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.28, p.29, p.30, p.31, p.32, p.58, p.59, p.61, p.91, p.92, p.193} ~ Prevalence of people who have ever used drugs that wanted to reduce their level of drug use but did not receive it, by age group and sex, by type of drug (cannabis, amphetamines, BZP party pills) {Cannabis Use 2012/13: New Zealand Health Survey, 2015, p.13, p.29; National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.14;  Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.32, p.33, p.34, p.35, p.61, p.62, p.92, p.193} ~ Reasons for not having received help to reduce the level of drug use by age and sex and type of drug (cannabis) {Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.35, p.62} ~ Sources of help to reduce the level of drug use in lifetime, among people aged 16–64 years who had ever received help to reduce their level of drug use (unadjusted prevalence): Drug and alcohol counsellor, Family member or friend, General practitioner (GP), Psychiatrist, psychologist or mental health service, Narcotics Anonymous or other support group, Detoxification program, Natural or alternative therapist, Māori or Pacific health service, Emergency department at a public hospital {Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.30, p.61, p.91} ~

Metric: Level of access to opioid substitution treatment and medication assisted treatment (OST/MAT)
Level of coverage of inpatient treatment
Proportion of people who use drugs enrolled in voluntary treatment
Proportion of people who use drugs enrolled in coerced treatment
Indicators: Among past-year drug users, % who reported that a relative or friend, or a doctor or another health worker had been concerned about them or suggested they cut down their use of  drugs (cannabis, amphetamines, BZP party pills) in the last 12 months and the % of the total population aged 16–64 years this proportion represents {Drug Use in New Zealand: Key Results of the 2007/08 New Zealand Alcohol and Drug Use Survey, 2010, p.62, p.92, p.193} ~ Percentage of drug users who reported someone being concerned about their drug use or suggested cutting down (Never; In the last 12 months; Earlier time) by type of drug (cannabis), by sex {Cannabis Use 2012/13: New Zealand Health Survey, 2015, p.27, p.28} ~

Metric: Proportion of people who use drugs enrolled in compulsory treatment
Presence of prevention programming in law enforcement
Presence of prevention programming in the media
Presence of prevention programming in schools
Presence of prevention programming in the workplace
Presence of prevention programming for youth and the community
Indicators: percentage of high school age students that thought it was okay for people their age to drink alcohol, and percentage that thought it was okay to use cannabis {National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.14} ~

Metric: Presence of other demand reduction metrics
Indicators: Cost of intervention by drug group (Amphetamine-type stimulants, Cannabinoids, Hallucinogenic and psychedelic drugs, Opioid and sedative drugs) and intervention type(Police/ Customs*, Courts/ Corrections, health) {The New Zealand Drug Harm Index, 2016, p.30} ~

Metric: Size and value of the illegal drug market
Indicators: Reinvestment in organized crime by drug group (Amphetamine-type stimulants, Cannabinoids, Hallucinogenic and psychedelic drugs, Opioid and sedative drugs) and user type (Expenditure on illicit drugs ($m): Dependent, Casual; Reinvestment in organized crime ($m): Dependent, Casual, Total) {The New Zealand Drug Harm Index, 2016, p.26} ~ Reinvestment in organized crime per user(Number of users: Dependent, Casual; Reinvestment in organized crime per user $: Dependent, Casual, All users) by Drug group(Amphetamine-type stimulants, Cannabinoids, Hallucinogenic and psychedelic drugs, Opioid and sedative drugs) {The New Zealand Drug Harm Index, 2016, p.27} ~ Tax avoided by organized crime by tax type and source of income(Income derived from dependent users: tax avoided ($m), Income derived from casual users: tax avoided ($m), Income from all users) by drug group(Amphetamine-type stimulants, Cannabinoids, Hallucinogenic and psychedelic drugs, Opioid and sedative drugs) {The New Zealand Drug Harm Index, 2016, p.28} ~

Metric: Level of procedures related to crop eradication
Number of arrests, seizures, and offences
Level of law enforcement activity and interdiction in the market
Indicators: amount prevented of pseudoephedrine(in kg) and of ephedrine(in kg) from entering the country and being used in the domestic methamphetamine manufacturing process by New Zealand Police, the Organized and Financial Crime Agency of New Zealand and the New Zealand Customs Service {National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.22} ~

Metric: Price, purity and potency of drugs, and related process indicators
Number of people engaged with the criminal justice system
Indicators: Legal problems reported among male (% included) and female (% included) cannabis users {Cannabis Use 2012/13: New Zealand Health Survey, 2015, p.12} ~ Legal problems reported by people who use drugs by age (% included) {Cannabis Use 2012/13: New Zealand Health Survey, 2015, p.12} ~ During 2013/14 (i.e., fiscal year ending 30 June 2014) number of police proceedings for illicit drug possession or use against youth (aged 5–24) that were recorded, with approximately a quarter resulting in court action {National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.9} ~

Metric: Presence of other supply reduction metrics
Indicators: Amount of money that has been estimated to cost the country per year by harmful use of AOD which includes: the costs to the criminal justice system of enforcing AOD-related legislation {National Drug Policy 2015-2020, 2015, p.2} ~

Metric: Level of engagement in international cooperation
Level of availability of harm reduction services and harm reduction scale up
Indicators: Number and % of MARPs reached with services (BCC, condoms/BCC, NSE) in past year: PWID {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p.62} ~ Number of occasions that stock outs of essential drugs and commodities reported (reported separately for condoms) {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p.67} ~ number of MARA/EVA reached with comprehensive risk reduction counseling services {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.34} ~ % of MARA/EVA that achieve effective coverage of condom services in target locations {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.35} ~

Metric: Presence of needle and syringe programs
Indicators: % of MARA/EVA that achieve effective coverage of Needle and Syringe exchange services in target locations {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.35} ~  Number of occasions that stock outs of essential drugs and commodities reported (reported separately for Needles/syringes) {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p.67} ~

Metric: Prevalence of substance use disorders
Indicators: estimated number of people who use drugs that are to suffer from drug use disorders, and of those, number of people who inject drugs (PWID) {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.63} ~ Percentage Age distribution of the drug abusers from 2012-2016 {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.28} ~ percentage distribution of patients by principal drug of abuse from 2012-2016 {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p. 32} ~ % of drug addicts that are adolescents and youths {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.57} ~

Metric: Prevalence of psychiatric comorbidities
Drug-related mortality
Indicators: an estimated number of drug-related deaths in 2014, corresponding to number of deaths of people aged 15-64 {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.63} ~

Metric: Prevalence of drug-related infectious disease
Indicators: Percentage of HIV prevalence amongst People Who Inject Drugs (PWID) {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p.16, Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.63, National Harm Reduction Strategy for Drug Use and HIV 2004-2010, 2008, p.1} ~ Percentage of most at risk populations who are HIV infected: male and female PWID, FSW, MSW, MSM, Hijra(transgender) {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p.60} ~  the % increase in HIV prevalence among IDUs by 2005-2006 in Central Bangladesh {National Harm Reduction Strategy for Drug Use and HIV 2004-2010, 2008, p.1} ~ % prevalence rates of Hepatitis C among IDUs {National Harm Reduction Strategy for Drug Use and HIV 2004-2010, 2008, p.7} ~ The % overall HIV prevalence among key populations of all ages {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.9} ~

Metric: Proportion of people who use drugs who engage in risky consumption
Indicators: the overall % of people that reported common needle sharing {National Harm Reduction Strategy for Drug Use and HIV 2004-2010, 2008, p.6} ~ during the month prior to the survey,  the average number of times IDUs reported injecting using a working syringe {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.11} ~

Metric: Proportion of people who use drugs who engage in safe consumption practices
Indicators: Percentage of PWID reporting use of new needle/syringe last time they injected {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p.61, National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.1} ~

Metric: Coverage of services for the prevention, testing, and treatment of bloodborne diseases
Indicators: Percentage of most at risk populations or emerging vulnerable populations who both correctly identify ways of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV and who reject major misconceptions about HIV transmission: PWID and Heroin smokers {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p. 62} ~ % of more vulnerable populations reached through HIV interventions {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p.63} ~ number of MARA / EVA connected via social media and linked to HIV services {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.34} ~ In terms of HIV testing, % of people that knew about a facility where they could be HIV tested and % of people that had been tested {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.11} ~ number of MARA/EVA reached through PE and linked to HIV services {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.34} ~ % of MARA/EVA that achieve effective coverage of HCT(HIV Counselling and Testing) services in target locations {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.34} ~ % of female MARA/EVA that achieve effective coverage of PPTCT(Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission) services in target locations {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.35} ~ number of reference group for MARA/EVA established {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.33} ~

Metric: Presence of specialised training for addiction care
Indicators: Echo Training: ln total 144 participants from different background (doctor, nurse, recovered addict, clinic owner, clinical psychologist, psychologist etc.) were trained on universal treatment curriculum {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p. 53} ~ number of partners trained in bottleneck analysis of the access and utilization of key HIV and AIDS Intervention {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.36} ~ number of service providers trained {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.34} ~

Metric: Presence of health harms related to drug use
Indicators: STI prevalence among all most at risk populations (for adults and young people): PWID and Heroin smokers {3rd National Strategic Plan for HIV and AIDS Response, 2011-2015, p.61} ~

Prevalence of alcohol and drugs in accidents, and interventions to increase road safety

Coverage of social assistance for people who use drugs (not including housing)

Metric: Number of households enrolled in alternative development
Presence of other development metrics
Indicators: Educational status of the drug abusers from 2012-2016 {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.29} ~ Distribution of patients by Employment Status, Self-income and Self-Occupation  from 2012-2016 {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.30, p.31, p.53} ~ low levels of formal education among MARP/EVA: % of PWIDs(People With Injecting Disorders) {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.24} ~

Prevalence of vulnerable people who use drugs (incarcerated individuals, people of color, people who experience homelessness, LGBTQ+ community, sex workers)

Distribution of sterile injecting equipment in prisons

Indicators: number of social protection programme with MARA/EVA sensitive indicators {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.33} ~

Metric: Prevalence of drug use by age
Indicators: Frequency distribution of Patients by Primary Drug, By Age etc. for 2012-2013 {Department of Narcotics Control, p.7} ~ The total estimated size after all adjustments for PWID in Bangladesh between aged 10- 24 yrs; Of these number of people that are in the age category 10-19 yrs. and 20-24 years {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.11} ~ number of young people, who are drug users, mostly Yaba (methamphetamine), that were surveyed, among which proportion of people that was in the age group of 10-18 years, average age of the respondents, with females being somewhat younger (18.5 yrs.) than males (19.6 yrs.) {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.14} ~ number of studies, survey and programme reports that are age disaggregated {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.32} ~ The mean age of first injecting drugs and first smoking heroin {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.11, p.12} ~

Metric: Prevalence of drug use by sex
Indicators: number of young people, who are drug users, mostly Yaba (methamphetamine), that were surveyed, among which proportion of people that was in the age group of 10-18 years, average age of the respondents, with females being somewhat younger (18.5 yrs.) than males (19.6 yrs.) {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.14} ~ % of male that reported taking Phensidyl before starting Yaba {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.14} ~

Metric: Prevalence of drug use by type
Indicators: the graphical presentation of three main drugs of abuse in Bangladesh(opioids, cannabinoids, stimulants) from 2012-2016 {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.54} ~ Besides heroin, % of smokers that took other drugs in the last six months which includes cannabis, Phensidyle, Pethidine, yaba, and Cocktail (mixture of different drugs) {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.12} ~ % of the respondents admitted to taking other drugs before they started taking Yaba. Cannabis was found to be the most common drug to start with (% included) while certain % of people used tablets {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.14} ~ proportion of people that admitted to injecting drugs before they took Yaba {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.14} ~  % of male that reported taking Phensidyl before starting Yaba {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.14} ~ Frequency distribution of Patients by Primary Drug, By Age etc. for 2012-2013 {Department of Narcotics Control, p.7} ~ number of young people, who are drug users, mostly Yaba (methamphetamine), that were surveyed, among which proportion of people that was in the age group of 10-18 years, average age of the respondents, with females being somewhat younger (18.5 yrs.) than males (19.6 yrs.) {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.14} ~ The total estimated size after all adjustments for PWID in Bangladesh between aged 10- 24 yrs; Of these number of people that are in the age category 10-19 yrs. and 20-24 years {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.11} ~

Metric: Number of people who use drugs

Indicators: Distribution of Patients by Route of Administration of Drugs in Bangladesh (smoking, swallowing, nasal inhalation, injection, others) from 2013-2016 {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.54} ~ the number of people that are believed to be injecting drug users (IDUs) out of the estimated number of total drug users {National Harm Reduction Strategy for Drug Use and HIV 2004-2010, 2008, p.5} ~ approximate % of drug users that are starting to inject with each passing year over the past five years {National Harm Reduction Strategy for Drug Use and HIV 2004-2010, 2008, p.6} ~ The mean age of first injecting drugs and first smoking heroin {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.11, p.12} ~  Proportion of people who reported that they had also injected drugs in the last six months; includes an estimated average {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.12} ~ estimated number of people who use drugs that are to suffer from drug use disorders, and of those, number of people who inject drugs (PWID) {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p .63} ~ The total estimated size after all adjustments for PWID in Bangladesh between aged 10- 24 yrs; Of these number of people that are in the age category 10-19 yrs. and 20-24 years {National HIV Risk Reduction Strategy for MARA/EVA to HIV & AIDS in Bangladesh, 2013, p.11} ~

Indicators: number of OST clinics in Dhaka, and number of PWIDs covered Who Inject Drugs) {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.51} ~ Prevalence of coverage of existing OST programmes in Bangladesh, and number of PWIDs covered. {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.51} ~

Indicators: The government has planned to establish more six treatment and rehabilitation centers with facilities of 50 beds in each divisional headquarters {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.52} ~ Number of Patients (inpatient, total) in private treatment centers from 1990 to 2016 {Department of Narcotics Control, p.7} ~

Indicators: Statistics on Preventive and Awareness Programmes: Prevention Education and Publication (Production & distribution of anti-narcotics posters, Distribution of anti-narcotics leaflets, Distribution of anti-narcotics stickers, souvenir, bulletin)from 2013-2016 {Annual Drug Report Bangladesh, 2016, p.49} ~

Metric: Level of procedures related to crop eradication

Metric: Level of law enforcement activity and interdiction in the market

Metric: Presence of other supply reduction metrics
Indicators: The number of registered applications, including the number of messages, including the fact that they were joined to the AEC earlier by one fact {Sectoral program on combating drug addiction and drug trafficking in the Republic of Kazakhstan, 2012-2016, np} ~ Number of penitentiary systems functioning (minimum security; high security; providing special treatment prison colonies; somatic hospitals; tuberculosis hospitals; juvenile corrective facilities; tightened regime; pre-trial detention centres) {National Report on Drug Situation in the Republic of Kazakhstan, 2012, p.83} ~

Metric: Level of engagement in international cooperation
Indicators: number of cases that were held in conjunction with the State Drug Control Service of the Kyrgyz Republic {Sectoral program on combating drug addiction and drug trafficking in the Republic of Kazakhstan, 2012-2016, np} ~ The agencies that implement harm reduction programmes in the Republic of Kazakhstan {National Report on Drug Situation in the Republic of Kazakhstan, 2012, p.95} ~ Number of non-governmental organisations and AIDS centres involved in the implementation of preventive activities conducted by the Global Fund to fight AIDS, TB, and Malaria in Kazakhstan {National Report on Drug Situation in the Republic of Kazakhstan, 2012, p.96} ~ Number of medical staff and outreach workers trained using funds from the GFATM grant {National Report on Drug Situation in the Republic of Kazakhstan, 2012, p.96} ~ Number of projects implemented by the UNODC in Kazakhstan (terrorism and crime prevention; fight against corruption and money laundering for the prevention of illicit drug trafficking; the prevention of drug use; the treatment of drug addiction; and the prevention and treatment of HIV infection among drug users in places of confinement) {National Report on Drug Situation in the Republic of Kazakhstan, 2012, p.97} ~
